This theorem states that for every real number `a` that is greater than zero, the infinite series with terms given by `2 * (1 / (2 * k + 1)) * (1 / (2 * a + 1)) ^ (2 * k + 1)` converges (has a sum), and this sum is equivalent to the natural logarithm of `(1 + a‚Åª¬π)`. Here, `k` is the index of the terms in the series, starting from zero and increasing by one with each term. Essentially, this theorem presents an expansion of the expression `log (1 + a‚Åª¬π)` as a power series in terms of `1 / (2 * a + 1)`.

name: Real.hasSum_log_one_add_inv
docString: This theorem states that for every real number `a` that is greater than zero, the infinite series with terms given by `2 * (1 / (2 * k + 1)) * (1 / (2 * a + 1)) ^ (2 * k + 1)` converges (has a sum), and this sum is equivalent to the natural logarithm of `(1 + a‚Åª¬π)`. Here, `k` is the index of the terms in the series, starting from zero and increasing by one with each term. Essentially, this theorem presents an expansion of the expression `log (1 + a‚Åª¬π)` as a power series in terms of `1 / (2 * a + 1)`.

For any `n`, we have `log_stirlingSeq 1 - log_stirlingSeq n ‚â§ 1/4 * ‚àë' 1/k^2`

name: Stirling.log_stirlingSeq_bounded_aux
docString: For any `n`, we have `log_stirlingSeq 1 - log_stirlingSeq n ‚â§ 1/4 * ‚àë' 1/k^2`

For every positive real number `a`, the infinite series $\sum\_{k=0}^\infty \frac{2}{(2k+1)(2a+1)} \cdot \left(\frac{1}{2a+1}\right)^{(2k+1)}$ converges and equals $\log(1+\frac{1}{a})$.

name: Real.hasSum_log_one_add_inv
docString: For every positive real number `a`, the infinite series $\sum\_{k=0}^\infty \frac{2}{(2k+1)(2a+1)} \cdot \left(\frac{1}{2a+1}\right)^{(2k+1)}$ converges and equals $\log(1+\frac{1}{a})$.

This theorem states that for any natural number `n`, the logarithm of the `Stirling.stirlingSeq` sequence at `n+1` minus the logarithm of the same sequence at `n+2` is less than or equal to `1/(4*(n+1)^2)`. In mathematical terms, for each `n` in the natural numbers, we have the inequality `log(stirlingSeq(n+1)) - log(stirlingSeq(n+2)) ‚â§ 1/(4*(n+1)^2)`.

name: Stirling.log_stirlingSeq_sub_log_stirlingSeq_succ
docString: This theorem states that for any natural number `n`, the logarithm of the `Stirling.stirlingSeq` sequence at `n+1` minus the logarithm of the same sequence at `n+2` is less than or equal to `1/(4*(n+1)^2)`. In mathematical terms, for each `n` in the natural numbers, we have the inequality `log(stirlingSeq(n+1)) - log(stirlingSeq(n+2)) ‚â§ 1/(4*(n+1)^2)`.
